javanews.object
Class PortReader

java.lang.Object
  javanews.object.PortReader
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Runnable
public class PortReader
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable

Used to receive data from a named COM port. The application allows for any named port to be accessed providing it is recognised as a Serial port by the underlying RxTx libraries. Multiple instances of this class can be used to access multiple COM ports with each class instance accessing a uniquely named port.

Each port must be freely accessible for the application to work correctly with it and so there cannot any other application attempting to access the same port as JavaNews. The COM port configuration window can be used to identify whether a port is in use by another application. This window should also be used to set the configuration values for each port as it contains the supported values for each setting.

The application expects COM port configuration values to be one of those listed below. JavaNews uses restricted values for user entry (in the COM port configuration window) and verification of values here to ensure that no invalid values can be configured with a port and thus cause system instability either for the application or for the platform on which it is operating.

Supported Argument Values:

The following lists show supported values for each of the arguments required when configuring a COM port. While the constructor will accept any values compatible with the given data type, only certain values are supported by the RxTx configuration and the COM port itself. These, accepted, values are listed below and should any value not be supported those shown as default values will be used instead.

Baud Rate (bps)

  • 110
  • 300
  • 600
  • 1200
  • 2400
  • 4800
  • 9600 - Default Value
  • 14400
  • 19200
  • 38400
  • 57600
  • 115200

Data Length (bits)

  • 5
  • 6
  • 7
  • 8 - Default Value

Parity Type

  • Even
  • Odd
  • Mark
  • None - Default Value

Stop Bit (size of, in bits)

  • 1 - Default Value
  • 1.5
  • 2

Version:
1.000
Author:
Alex Harris (email: Alexander.J.Harris(at)btinternet.com)

Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

PortReader

public PortReader(java.lang.String name,
                  int baud,
                  int data,
                  java.lang.String parity,
                  float stop,
                  COMPortClient cpcParent)
Initialises the class and its internal logger. It uses the supplied arguments for the configuration of the COM port to read data accurately and read data from it.

As the arguments are of types that support any value, there are checks in place to ensure that unsupported values are not passed to the COM port which may crash the program. Please refer to the notes on the class for more information about support values and default values.

Parameters:
name - The identifying name of the COM port See the class notes.
baud - The baud rate to be used See the class notes.
data - The number of bits used to carry data See the class notes.
parity - The type of parity to be used See the class notes.
stop - The number of bits used for the stop bit See the class notes.
cpcParent - The parent instance used to output data to
Method Detail

run

public void run()
Starts the thread running using either a normal COM port (COM1 - COM98) or to use the test port which reads data from a local file (COM99).

Specified by:
run in interface java.lang.Runnable
See Also:
accessCOMPort(), runTestPort()

accessCOMPort

private void accessCOMPort()
Receives input from a COM port and stores it within an instance of StringBuffer for further processing. On receipt of a return character from the COM port the contents of the StringBuffer is passed to an instance of MsgFormatter to interpret the contents of the message.

This method uses the RxTx libraries to access the COM port, configure it and read data from it.

This method is solely responsible for receiving the data from the COM port, not interpreting it. This should allow the application as a whole to respond quickly to incoming data in the event of sudden influxes of data. The MsgFormatter is responsible for handling messages received here and their vetting, interpretation and storage in the database.

See Also:
MsgFormatter

runTestPort

private void runTestPort()
Runs a simulated port which can be used for testing where a COM port or PSE might not be available. The test port enumerates the OpenNewsSample.txt file and stores the contents line-by-line in a Vector which is then sequentially passed to an instance of MsgFormatter for further processing.

This is repeated at a higher rate than would normally be expected on a typical PSE network as messages through the test port are generated at 1 per 10ms and is intended to duplicate prolonged periods of high volume.

getBaud

private int getBaud()
Verifies and returns a supported value for the baud rate to be used for the COM port. If the value originally supplied for use with the COM port cannot be supported then the value is changed to a default on of 9600bps.

Returns:
The baud rate supported on RxTx with the COM port

getShouldRun

private boolean getShouldRun()
Checks whether the monitoring loops should continue to execute.

Returns:
The boolean value of whether iteration should continue.

setShouldRun

public void setShouldRun(boolean continueRunning)
Sets the value affecting the monitoring loops.

Parameters:
continueRunning - The new value for whether the threads should monitor the designated COM port.
